Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EAGER: The Language of the Forests: Gwich'in Seasonal Relationships to the Interior Alaska Boreal Forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates what Gwich'in Athabascans can teach the world, through their language, about boreal forest management in interior Alaska. The focus is on the Athabascan villages of Beaver and Artic where many elders who have lived a subsistence lifestyle reside. Studying Gwich'in forestry management in the Gwich'in language will provide an understanding of the human-environment interaction as a way to create more opportunities for co-management. This project will advance knowledge about forestry management for natural resources managers, and add to the growing body of regional work to promote Indigenous knowledge practice and sustainable management of natural resources. While this project incorporates ideas as well as approaches from current forestry and languages projects, it is also creating new information. This information will provide reliable/tested forestry practices for those interested in the incorporation of Indigenous Knowledge into natural resources management, and will be shared with other villages. The opportunity to establish a Gwich'in forestry practices approach is missing in co-management as well as adaptive management between Indigenous and non-Indigenous agencies. Using management as one of the focal points of this project, the project will document the endangered Gwich'in language in a manner that is not archival, but alive.

This project represents the application of a newly developed model for research, the co-production of scientific knowledge, bringing established forestry management science research together with Gwich'in knowledge holders in order to produce a more contextualized and holistic understanding of the boreal forest. The study will be the first to document Gwich'in forestry practices in a collaborative social and linguistic science investigation. Considered an endangered language, Gwich'in elders who are both fluent speakers and have lived a subsistence lifestyle will be interviewed in the Gwich'in language as a means to communicate complex seasonal management practices of the boreal forests. For this study, language is the vehicle to understand the deep place-based relationship Gwich'in people have with the forests. The core research question centers not only on how Gwich'in people practice forestry management but also on how their relationship to the forests change or evolve seasonally. While this project will not exhaust the discussion, the intention is to accomplish three objectives: 1. Demonstrate the usefulness of Gwich'in forestry knowledge and practices, 2. Record Gwich'in in this context and, 3. Provide a way forward in the co-management of the Alaska's interior boreal forests. Given the objectives, the potential contributions and implications of this study span a number of natural resources co-management opportunities: fire suppression and arctic boreal encroachment, as well as environmental change preparation-adaptation-mitigation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Joseph P. Brewer II has completed the pilot study “Language of the Forests: Gwich’in Seasonal Relationships to the Interior Alaska Boreal Forests,” supported by an NSF EAGER Arctic Social Sciences grant. During the funding period he traveled to Fort Yukon, Arctic Village, and Fairbanks, Alaska to facilitate six interviews done mostly in the Gwich’in language with fluent Gwich’in speaking knowledge holders. As an ecologist, Brewer was interested in understanding the deep spatial and temporal knowledge/relationship Gwich’in maintain with the Northern Boreal Forest seasonally. He was specifically focused on documenting Gwich’in words and phrases for tree species and stewardship techniques implored by Gwich’in People, and focused on further understanding how the Gwich’in language can facilitate a more robust comprehension of practical working knowledge of the boreal forests.

Brewer accomplished the goal of his research by documenting the Gwich’in language in the context of the boreal forests, and worked to facilitate transcriptions and translate interviews. Data from this project is actually knowledge, and is the basis for a position that an effort can be made by natural resources management offices to better understand Gwich’in perspectives of stewardship practices in the boreal forest that demonstrates a positive approach to co-management. He worked with Gwich’in culture bearers to translate the interviews in a manner that is both culturally respectful and informative. He also worked with the Alaska Native Language Center to house all the project materials on site for future interested Gwich’in communities, natural resources offices, and future researchers. He helped to continue to shape methodologies for distance work that build upon previously established ethnographic methodologies done in similar studies. He has written a book chapter, for a book on Indigenous People’s inherent sovereign rights in the research process, and is working on drafts for other publications, and has given presentations that include project findings. He was able to explore important stewardship features from a Gwich’in perspective, which help inform future writing and presentations that differentiate stewardship and management, and how this might better inform co-management opportunities. 

Brewer was able to learn that though the complex nature of the Gwich’in language is considerable, the knowledge carried in the language is equally as complex as well as instructional, and it is the hope that this approach can better inform co-production of knowledge with Indigenous communities. The data Brewer collected while translating is clear, Gwich’in have a great deal to share with the world.
